pre-snap-reads.description: Coverage recognition, blitz identification, and formation analysis

questions.scenario: 3rd & 8, shotgun formation. You see two safeties at 12-yard depth, corners in press coverage, and linebackers at normal depth.
questions.question: What coverage should you expect?
questions.explanation: Two safeties at intermediate depth (12 yards) with press corners indicates Cover 2. The safeties will split deep halves while corners and linebackers cover underneath zones or man coverage.

questions.scenario: Pre-snap, you identify a single safety at 15-yard depth, corners playing off coverage, and the MLB showing blitz in the A-gap.
questions.question: What's your primary concern?

options.text: Deep post route will be open
Hot route needed over the middle
Running back checkdown will be covered

questions.explanation: With MLB blitzing in Cover 1, the middle of the field opens up. Your hot route should be a quick slant or hitch over the vacated middle linebacker area.

questions.scenario: You see corners playing inside leverage, two high safeties splitting the field, and linebackers dropping deeper than usual.
questions.question: This indicates what coverage concept?
questions.explanation: Inside corner leverage with two high safeties and dropping linebackers suggests quarters coverage - four deep defenders splitting deep zones with pattern matching underneath.

questions.scenario: Pre-snap, the safety starts walking down toward the line of scrimmage. The corner on that side begins backing up.
questions.question: What's happening?

options.text: Safety blitz with corner rotating deep

questions.explanation: When a safety walks down and the corner backs up, it's a late rotation blitz. The corner will take the safety's deep responsibility while the safety blitzes.

questions.scenario: You identify 6 potential rushers at the line of scrimmage. Your protection can handle 5.
questions.question: What's your first priority?

options.text: Call timeout to change the play

questions.explanation: With 6 rushers vs 5 blockers, someone will be free. Identify which receiver has the hot route to throw immediately when that rusher breaks free.

questions.scenario: The outside linebacker on the weak side is creeping closer to the line. The strong safety is also walking down.
questions.question: What blitz concept should you expect?
questions.explanation: With both the OLB and safety showing blitz on the strong side, expect an overload where multiple rushers attack from the same side to outnumber your blockers.

questions.scenario: You notice the free safety is aligned 8 yards deep directly over your slot receiver, with corners in press man coverage.
questions.question: What coverage and what's your best attack?

options.text: Cover 1 Robber - throw over the robber

questions.explanation: A safety sitting short over the slot with press corners indicates Cover 1 Robber. The safety will jump underneath routes, so throw over him or attack the edges where he can't help.

questions.scenario: The defense shows 8 men in the box with a single high safety. Your formation has 3 receivers to one side.
questions.question: What's the defense likely trying to stop and how should you attack?

options.text: Stopping the run - throw a quick fade
Stopping the pass - run the ball
Stopping the run - throw to the trips side

questions.explanation: 8 in the box means they're stopping the run. With trips to one side, that side has a numbers advantage in the passing game. Attack the trips side with quick timing routes.

post-snap-decisions.description: Progression reads, route concepts, and decision-making after the snap

questions.scenario: Running four verticals against Cover 2, your #2 receiver (slot) sits in the hole between the safeties. The MLB is dropping to cover him.
questions.question: Where should you look?
questions.explanation: In Cover 2 vs four verticals, if the MLB takes the slot receiver in the seam, the running back should be open underneath for an easy completion and YAC opportunity.

questions.scenario: Your primary read (15-yard out) is covered by a linebacker sitting in the throwing lane. The safety is covering your deep route.
questions.question: What's your best option?

options.text: Force the throw to the out route

questions.explanation: With the linebacker jumping the out route and safety deep, the intermediate crossing route should find the soft spot in the coverage between levels.

questions.scenario: Running a smash concept (corner-speed out combination) vs Cover 3. The corner sits on the speed out, and the safety rotates to the corner route.
questions.question: Your move?

options.text: Throw the corner route before safety arrives

questions.explanation: When both parts of the smash concept are covered, the backside routes should be working against lighter coverage. Check your progression to the other side.

questions.scenario: You're running trips bunch formation with a pick play. The defense switches the pick, putting both receivers in man coverage.
questions.question: What happens to your timing?

options.text: Delay slightly for receivers to clear
Throw to the original route regardless

questions.explanation: When defenses switch picks in man coverage, you need to allow an extra beat for your receivers to create separation after the switch before delivering the ball.

questions.scenario: Post-snap, you see the safety rotating late to help on your primary receiver running a comeback route.
questions.question: Where is the void in coverage likely to be?

options.text: Deep over the middle where safety came from
In the flat where the safety vacated

questions.explanation: When a safety rotates late to help on a route, he leaves a void in his original area. The deep middle area he vacated is now vulnerable to crossing routes or posts.

questions.scenario: You're in the pocket and see your slot receiver break open on a slant, but a linebacker is charging the throwing lane.
questions.question: How do you complete this pass?

options.text: Throw a bullet over the linebacker
Throw low to avoid the linebacker
Pump fake to freeze the linebacker first
Step up and throw around the linebacker

questions.explanation: Step up in the pocket to change your throwing angle. This allows you to throw around the linebacker rather than over him, giving your receiver a better chance to catch and secure the ball.

situational-awareness.description: Down and distance, field position, clock management, and game situation decisions

questions.scenario: 1st & 10 at your opponent's 35-yard line. The defense is showing single high safety with corners playing soft.
questions.question: What's your best approach?

options.text: Run a quick 5-yard hitch for easy completion
Hand the ball off to establish run

questions.explanation: In plus territory with soft coverage, attack the intermediate level. This gives you a high-percentage throw with good YAC potential and keeps you ahead of the chains.

questions.scenario: 3rd & 12 from your own 15-yard line. The defense shows Cover 2.
questions.question: What's your priority?

options.text: Throw deep and hope for PI call

questions.explanation: On 3rd & long from deep in your territory, you need to convert. The seam between safeties in Cover 2 gives you the best chance to get the first down without risking a pick-six.

questions.scenario: You're at the opponent's 12-yard line, 2nd & goal. The defense shows goal line personnel (6 DBs).
questions.question: What concept gives you the best chance?
questions.explanation: Against goal line defense with extra DBs, a rollout gives you multiple options: throw to open receiver, run if the edge is open, or throw it away if nothing's there.

questions.scenario: Backed up at your own 8-yard line, 2nd & 15 after a holding penalty.
questions.question: What's your primary concern?

options.text: Getting positive yards to help the punter

questions.explanation: Deep in your end zone, ball security is paramount. Take what the defense gives you and avoid turnovers or safeties that would give your opponent points and possession.

questions.scenario: Two-minute warning, down by 3, at your own 25-yard line with 1 timeout remaining.
questions.question: What's your approach on this drive?

options.text: Aggressive deep shots to score quickly
Conservative short passes to move chains
Mix of intermediate routes and sideline throws
Run the ball to control clock

questions.explanation: With limited timeouts, you need efficient yardage while managing clock. Mix intermediate routes for chunks with sideline throws to stop the clock and preserve your timeout.

questions.scenario: 4th & 3 at the opponent's 38-yard line, early in the 2nd quarter, game tied 7-7.
questions.question: What factors should influence your decision?

options.text: Always punt - too early to be aggressive
Always go - field position is too good
Consider wind, defense tendencies, and your offense's success rate
Kick field goal for guaranteed points

questions.explanation: 4th & 3 in plus territory requires situational analysis: your team's 4th down success rate, opponent's short-yardage defense, weather conditions, and momentum factors all matter.

red-zone-tactics.description: Red zone concepts, goal line situations, and condensed field passing

questions.scenario: Red zone, 3rd & goal from the 8. You see man coverage with a safety over your #1 receiver.
questions.question: What route gives you the best chance?

options.text: Quick slant to avoid the safety

questions.explanation: With man coverage and safety help over your best receiver, a pick play with slot receivers creates natural separation and gives you a higher percentage throw.

questions.scenario: 1st & goal from the 3. The defense shows 8 men in the box.
questions.question: What's your best red zone concept?
questions.explanation: With 8 in the box, a bootleg gets you outside the congestion and gives you dual threat capability - throw if someone's open, run if the edge is clear.

questions.scenario: Red zone, 2nd & goal from the 6. The defense is in Cover 2 man with the safeties sitting low at the goal line.
questions.question: Where is the best place to attack?

options.text: Over the top with fade routes
The back corners with corner routes

questions.explanation: With safeties sitting low in Cover 2, the back corners are vulnerable. Corner routes or back-shoulder fades to the corners of the end zone are your best options.

questions.scenario: Goal line, 4th & goal from the 1. The defense shows their biggest personnel package with 9 men in the box.
questions.question: What gives you the best chance to score?

options.text: Fade route to your tallest receiver

questions.explanation: With 9 in the box, the edges are vulnerable. A rollout gives you the option to throw to an open receiver, run it in yourself, or throw it away if nothing's there.

audibles-adjustments.description: Protection calls, route adjustments, and pre-snap modifications

questions.scenario: Pre-snap, you identify the mike linebacker in the A-gap, but your center is pointing to the outside linebacker.
questions.question: What should you do?
questions.explanation: If there's confusion about the mike identification, you need to make sure everyone is on the same page by clearly calling out the mike linebacker to set proper protection.

questions.scenario: You see a safety walking down late, creating a 6th potential rusher. Your protection is set for 5.
questions.question: Your best adjustment is:

options.text: Slide protection to the blitz side
Keep the running back in to block
Hard count to try drawing them offsides

questions.explanation: With a 6th rusher, someone will be free. Having all receivers convert to hot routes ensures you have immediate options when the free rusher breaks through.

questions.scenario: You call a deep passing play, but at the line you see the defense has rotated to Cover 2 with 8 men in the box.
questions.question: What's your best audible option?

options.text: Keep the deep pass - fewer deep defenders
Call timeout to get a better play

questions.explanation: With 8 in the box showing run stop but Cover 2 over top, the underneath areas are vulnerable. Quick slants can exploit the soft underneath coverage.

questions.scenario: Your receiver motions across the formation and the linebacker follows him, confirming man coverage. Your original play was designed for zone.
questions.question: How should you adjust?

options.text: Signal receivers to run man-beating routes
Audible to a completely different play
Motion the receiver back to his original spot

questions.explanation: Once you've identified man coverage through motion, signal your receivers to convert their routes to man-beating concepts like slants, hitches, or comeback routes.

pocket-presence.description: Rush recognition, pocket movement, escape routes, and pressure management

questions.scenario: You feel pressure from both edges, but the pocket is clean up the middle.
questions.question: What's your best move?
questions.explanation: When edge rushers are coming but the middle is clean, step up into the pocket. This gives you more time and maintains your throwing angles to all receivers.

questions.scenario: The pocket is collapsing from all sides. Your checkdown is covered, and you're about to be sacked.
questions.question: What should you do?

options.text: Take the sack to avoid an interception
Throw the ball at a receiver's feet
Try to scramble for positive yards
Throw the ball out of bounds

questions.explanation: When all options are covered and a sack is imminent, throw the ball out of bounds to avoid the loss of yardage and preserve the down for your next play call.

questions.scenario: You're scrambling to your right when you see your receiver breaking open across the middle of the field.
questions.question: What's the key to making this throw?

options.text: Plant your feet and throw immediately
Keep running and throw off your back foot
Stop, set your feet, then throw across your body
Continue scrambling until you're directly behind him

questions.explanation: When scrambling right and throwing back across the field, you must stop and set your feet to generate proper velocity and accuracy on the cross-body throw.

questions.scenario: A defensive end has a clear rush lane up the middle. Your running back is supposed to pick him up but whiffs on the block.
questions.question: What's your immediate reaction?

options.text: Step up further to avoid him
Get rid of the ball immediately

questions.explanation: When a free rusher has a clear path and your protection breaks down, your internal clock should tell you to get rid of the ball immediately to your hot route or checkdown.
